prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for wearing earbuds and occasionally checking my phone during a church mass that I am forced to go to even though I am an atheist?
My parents have recently had a interest in going to church for the past month or so, so every Sunday, they force me to attend mass with them. I have told them multiple times that I don't believe in what they believe, but they brush it off and force me to come anyways. So this time, I brought earbuds and put on an album to listen to (Stokeley by Ski Mask the Slump God is great; listen to it) because I wanted to listen to my music instead. I would also text my friend every 15 minutes or so. During the entire mass, my mom shot me dirty looks the whole time and later told me on the ride home that I have a horribly negative attitude and that I should enjoy things more (even though I have told them countless times that I don't believe in what they do and dislike attending church.

Am I just being a bitch or are my parents at fault?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

But then again, even if the author is forced to attend, maybe there's an expectation to at least act respectfully during the service. However, the parents are also forcing the author to attend, which might infringe on the author's autonomy, especially if they're of age.

In terms of right or wrong, it's a bit of a gray area. The author's actions could be considered disrespectful in the context of the church, but the parents are also forcing them into a situation they don't believe in. The parents' reaction might be about respect versus the author's right to not participate. 

So, maybe the answer is B (No, the author is not in the wrong) because they are being forced to attend something they don't believe in and are trying to cope in a way that's respectful to their own beliefs.
